abstract.para: Check whether the cluster moves the virtual IP address to another node if the node that currently runs the resource is set to standby. This procedure uses example nodes called &node1; and &node2;, and the example IP address &subnetI;.10.

step.para: In the first terminal, ping the virtual IP address:
In the second terminal, log in to one of the cluster nodes.
Check which node the virtual IP address is running on:
step.screen:
&prompt.user;sudo crm status
[..]
Node List: * Online: [ &node1;.&exampledomain; &node2;.&exampledomain; ]
Full List of Resources: * admin-ip (ocf:heartbeat:IPaddr2): Started &node1;.&exampledomain;

step.para: Check the cluster status again. The resource admin-ip should have migrated to &node2;:
step.screen:
&prompt.user;sudo crm status
[...]
Node List: * Node &node1;.&exampledomain;: standby * Online: [ &node2;.&exampledomain; ]
Full List of Resources: * admin-ip (ocf:heartbeat:IPaddr2): Started &node2;.&exampledomain;

step.para: In the first terminal, you should see an uninterrupted flow of pings to the virtual IP address during the migration. This shows that the cluster setup and the floating IP address work correctly.
Cancel the ping command with C.
